Listing goal: Lists IP ranges belonging to officially published abuse addresses that either bounce or request not to receive abuse notices. The aim of this list is to block companies that openly shrug their abuse responsibilities.
Nomination: Abuse addresses that fail to be deliverable for 3 out of the last 7 days are automatically added.
Listing lifetime: Lifetime listing or automatic once mail delivery resumes in the case of automated additions.

Zone: Lists IP ranges belonging to abuse addresses that have failed to handle abuse issues for at least 30 days. The aim of this list is to hold companies accountable for the abuse that originates from their networks rather than just ignoring it.
Listing goal: IP ranges belonging to abuse addresses with reported and unresolved issues for at least 30 days are automatically added.
Nomination: Automatic removal is done once all hosts with abuse unresolved for 30 days have been clean for 2 weeks.
Listing lifetime: Data for lists are generated from live data collected by the WebIron web security platform.

Zone: Lists single IP addresses recently attacking websites and servers.
Listing goal: Lists IP addressed belonging to hosts that have attacked at least twice within the last 48 hours.
Nomination: Automatic removal is done once a host has gone 24 hours without an incident
Listing lifetime: Data for lists are generated from live data collected by the WebIron web security platform.

Zone: Contains IP addresses and ranges from BABL, CABL, and STABL
Web Crawler IP lookup used to match user agents with known crawler IP addresses. Data from this list is considered BETA.
Listing lifetime: This DNSRBL contains valid and legitimate crawlers. Matching alone should not be used for blocking

Listing goal: Extremely conservative list of single IP4 addresses that produce exclusively spam/malware as indicated by the GBUdb IP Reputation system. Most systems should be able to safely reject connections based on this list.
Nomination: Automatic: IPs are added when the GBUdb "cloud" statistics reach a probability figure that indicates 95% of messages produce a spam/malware pattern match and a confidence figure that indicates sufficient data to trust the probability data.
Listing lifetime: Automatic: Continuous while reputation statistics remain bad. Warning: Produces false positives, and has no remedy/removal process. IPs are dropped quickly if the statistics improve (within an hour). IPs are dropped within 36 hours (typ) if no more messages are seen (dead zombie).
Notes: Source data is derived from a global network of Message Sniffer[1] filtering nodes in real-time. Truncate data is updated from statistics every 10 minutes.

Listing goal: Single IP addresses which only send UBE. Specializing in snowshoe spam and other 'under the radar' spams which evade many other DNSBLs. Has FP-level comparable to Zen.
Nomination: Automatic (upon receipt of a spam to a real person's mailbox), with extensive whitelists and filtering to prevent false positives
Listing lifetime: Typically an automatic expiration 11 days after the last abuse was seen, but with some exceptions
Notes: Spam samples are always kept on file for each listing. Removal requests are manually reviewed and processed without fees.

Zone: Lists /24 blocks of IP addresses which usually only send UBE and containing at least several addresses which are confirmed emitters of junk mail. Collateral listings are kept to a minimum because subsections are often carved from /24 listings when spammers and legit senders share the same /24 block.
Listing goal: Automatic once at least several IP addresses from a given block are individually listed on ivmSIP, with extensive whitelists and filtering to prevent false positives
Nomination: Expiration time increases to many weeks as the fraction of IP addresses in the /24 block in question sending junk mail increases
Listing lifetime: Removal requests are quickly and manually reviewed and processed without fees.

Zone: Comparable to uribl.com and surbl.org, this is a list of IP addresses and domains which are used by spammers in the clickable links found in the body of spam messages
Listing goal: Automatic (upon receipt of a spam to a real person's mailbox), with extensive whitelists and filtering to prevent false positives
Nomination: Typically an automatic expiration several weeks after the last abuse was seen.
Listing lifetime: Spam samples are always kept on file for each listing. Removal requests are quickly and manually reviewed and processed without fees.

Listing goal: {{strikethrough|Lists all types of open (publicly accessible) proxies}}
Listing lifetime: {{strikethrough|As long as proxy is verified open (automated)}}[2] Service discontinued mid 2014
Notes: {{strikethrough|Time between verifications increases exponentially in relation to the number of times the host was verified an open proxy}}

Listing goal: Single IP addresses that send mail to spamtraps
Nomination: Automatic by a cluster of more than 60 trapservers [4]
Listing lifetime: Automatic expiration 7 days after the last abuse was seen, optionally express delisting for a small fee.
Notes: UCEPROTECT's primary and the only independent list

Zone: Allocations with exceeded UCEPROTECT Level 1 listings
Nomination: Automatic removal as soon as Level 1 listings decrease below Level 2 listing border, optionally express delisting (for a fee)
Listing lifetime: Fully depending on Level 1

Zone: ASN's with excessive UCEPROTECT Level 1 listings
Nomination: Automatic removal as soon as Level 1 listings decrease below Level 3 listing border, optionally express delisting (fee)
Listing lifetime: Fully depending on Level 1

Blacklist operator: Spam and Open Relay Blocking System (SORBS)
Listing lifetime: N/A (See individual zones)
Notes: Aggregate zone (all aggregates and what they include are listed on SORBS)[5]

Listing lifetime: Safe Aggregate zone (all zones in dnsbl.sorbs.net except "recent", "old", "spam" and "escalations")
Those not already listed in the HTTP or SOCKS databases

Zone: IP addresses with vulnerabilities that are exploitable by spammers (e.g. FormMail scripts)
Nomination: Until delisting requested or Automated Expiry

Zone: Hosts that have sent spam to the admins of SORBS or SORBS Spamtraps in the last 48 hours
Nomination: Renewed every 20 minutes based inclusion in on 'spam.dnsbl.sorbs.net'

Zone: Hosts that have sent spam to the admins of SORBS or SORBS Spamtraps in the last 28 days
Nomination: Renewed every 20 minutes based inclusion in on 'spam.dnsbl.sorbs.net'

Zone: Hosts that have sent spam to the admins of SORBS or SORBS Spamtraps in the last year
Nomination: Renewed every 20 minutes based inclusion in on 'spam.dnsbl.sorbs.net'

Zone: Hosts that have allegedly sent spam to the admins of SORBS or SORBS Spamtraps at any time
Netblocks of service providers believed to support spammers
Nomination: Until delisting requested and matter resolved.
Listing lifetime: Service providers are added on receipt of a 'third strike' spam

Zone: Hosts demanding that they never be tested

Listing lifetime: Not a list of dial-up IP addresses

Zone: No Servers Permitted by ISP Policy
Listing lifetime: No Servers Permitted by ISP Policy

Zone: Domains with invalid A or MX records in DNS
Listing goal: Open submission via automated testing page.

Zone: Domains which the owners have confirmed will not be used for sending email

Listing goal: Verified sources of spam, including spammers and their support services, per policy
Listing lifetime: From five minutes to a year or more, depending on issue and resolution

Zone: Illegal third-party exploits (e.g. open proxies, email spambots, malware download sites and botnets)
Nomination: Varies, under a month, self removal via Composite Blocking List lookup.
Listing lifetime: Consists of the Composite Blocking List

Zone: Addresses not meant to be initiating SMTP connections, such as residential dynamic IPs
Listing goal: Manual, by providers controlling the IPs or by Spamhaus PBL Team
Listing lifetime: Should not be confused with the MAPS DUL and Wirehub Dynablocker lists

Zone: A single lookup for querying the SBL and XBL databases
A single lookup for querying the SBL, XBL and PBL databases.
Listing lifetime: Preferred list to check all Spamhaus listings with one query.

Listing goal: {{strikethrough|Unsolicited bulk/Commercial email senders (/24 IP address block)}}
Listing lifetime: {{strikethrough|Until delisting requested? (Only when found to not be a spam source)}}Their web server is down[6] 2014-11-17 - Their RBL server is reporting all queries as SPAM.

Zone: cbl.abuseat.org (also free available rsync access, on request see FAQ [7])
Listing goal: Only IP addresses exhibiting characteristics specific to open proxies, spamware, malware downloaders, botnets and the like.
Nomination: Automatic: large spamtraps, production mail servers and other detecton methods.
Listing lifetime: Less than a month after last listable event, self-removal via CBL lookup.
Notes: Use Spamhaus XBL or Spamhaus Zen instead
This DNSBL zone is part of the default configuration for Proventia Mail Security System and Lotus Protector for Mail Security

Listing goal: IP addresses used to send spam to trap
Listing lifetime: Temporary, until spam stops

Listing goal: IP addresses used to send spam to trap
Listing lifetime: Temporary, until spam stops

Listing goal: IP addresses used to send UBE to members
Listing lifetime: Temporary, until spam stops

Listing goal: IP Reputation based. Seems to be proprietary.
Listing lifetime: Temporary. Has self removal, users can not request delisting.
Notes: Accused by Spamhaus of unauthorized and undisclosed listings reuse.[8]

Listing goal: IP addresses which have been used to transmit reported email to SpamCop users
Listing lifetime: Temporary, until spam stops, has self removal

Listing goal: IP addresses detected as abusive at ISP's using MagicMail Servers, with no reverse DNS service
Listing lifetime: Listed until removed, and reverse DNS configured

Zone: IP addresses detected as abusive at ISP's using MagicMail Servers, with non-conforming reverse DNS service (See Best Practises) indicative of compromised systems
Nomination: Listed until removed, and reverse DNS set to conform to Best Practises

Zone: IP addresses detected as abusive at ISP's using MagicMail Servers, and manually confirmed as spam sources
IP addresses detected probing passwords or authenticating without sending mail

Listing goal: {{strikethrough|IP addresses and related generic netblocks that have sent spam.}}
Listing lifetime: {{strikethrough|Until removal requested and matter resolved by changing server DNS ptr record to a non-generic name.}}
Notes: {{strikethrough|Even if a particular IP has not sent spam, it may be included in a generic netblock which will provide many false positives. listed=127.0.0.2}} Offline since 2018-05-30.

Listing goal: {{strikethrough|IP addresses used to send spam to traps or members}}
Listing lifetime: {{strikethrough|Varies from spam type, rate and other sophisticated factors. 30 s to 1 week.}}
Notes: {{strikethrough|High IP network aggregate threshold greater than or equal 254.}} Offline since 2010. [9]

Listing goal: Detects viruses by behavior using fake high MX and tracking non-use of QUIT
Listing lifetime: Black list Data lives for 4 days. White list data lives for 10 days.

Listing goal: {{strikethrough|Aggregate zone, contains UCE/bulk email senders, open proxies, open relays, trojaned/infected machines, comment/trackback spammers}}
Listing lifetime: {{strikethrough|Until delisting requested}} As announced,[10] all public zones are no longer functioning (they return positive responses for all queries)
Notes: {{strikethrough|Aggregate zone (all aggregates and what they include are listed on AHBL)[11]}}

Zone: {{strikethrough|Domains sending spam, domains owned by spammers, comment spam domains, spammed URLs}}
Listing lifetime: {{yes|{{strikethrough|Yes}}}}

Zone: {{strikethrough|Subset of dnsbl, contains only open proxies, compromised machines, comment spammers}}
Listing lifetime: {{yes|{{strikethrough|Yes}}}}

Listing goal: {{strikethrough|Stop spam from hosts that send no legitimate mail (list most non-mail-sending hosts).}}
Nomination: {{strikethrough|Listings based on "instant" automated checks, recipient nomination and traps.}}
Listing lifetime: {{strikethrough|Listings can be challenged. Subscribers vote to decide sender status.}}
Notes: {{strikethrough|Public list follows standard dnsbl protocol. Subscription based service is more capable, but does not follow standard.}}

Blacklist operator: Heise Zeitschriften Verlag GmbH & Co. KG, hosted by manitu GmbH
Listing goal: Lists single IPs (no IP ranges) that send spam to spamtraps. Lists mailhosts, rather than domains, and thus blocks entire hosting providers and ISPs.
Nomination: Automated listing due to spamtrap hits. Exceptions apply to bounces, NDRs and whitelisted IPs.
Listing lifetime: 12 hours after last listing or until self delisting
Notes: TXT records provide information of listing incident - NiX Spam also provides hashes for fuzzy checksum plugin (iXhash) for SpamAssassin.

Nomination: IP addresses can be reported as known spam sources by users, additionally automated listing if spam arrives at the mailservers of inps.de
Listing lifetime: IP addresses are listed until they are removed manually via the website.
Notes: A- and TXT records are available for each entry
Collateral listings: Removal is free after 30 days for automatic additions and after 7 days for manual additions
Notifies upon listing: otherwise removal fee is at least EUR 10,00.

Listing goal: IP-Addresses who Attacks other Server/Honeypots over ssh, imap, smtp, ftp, web, rfi, sqli, ddos....
Nomination: Automatic: over Honeypots and with over 515 Users and 630 Servers from blocklist.de via Fail2Ban or own scripts
Listing lifetime: Automatic: 48 Hours after the last Attack. But earlier remove is available over the Delist-Link
Notes: Services is free! Source data is from Honeypot-Systems and over 515 User with 630 Servern there reports Attacks with Fail2Ban

Listing lifetime: Automatic expiry (varies by type)
Collateral listings: Removal requests are quickly and manually reviewed and processed without fees.

Listing goal: Spam sources from email, forums, referrer spam and dictionary attacks
Listing lifetime: Twelve months unless ISPs request removal earlier
Notes: By request. ISPs can provide request exclusion

Listing goal: IP addresses used to send spam to traps
Nomination: spamtraps, in order to avoid abusive reports (Competitors, false positive, etc...) only MegaRBL team can add an IP to the list.
Listing lifetime: Until delisting requested.
Notes: Removal requests are quickly and manually reviewed and processed without fees.

Nomination: List of IP addresses that sends spam or causing troubles with botnets or phishing
Listing lifetime: Until delisting requested.
Notes: Removal requests will be investigated and processed within 24 hours of submission. Previously known as IPrange.net RBL Project

Nomination: Provides a list of IP addresses which are sending spam. The Barracuda Reputation system uses automated collection methods to add and delete IP addresses from the BRBL.
Listing lifetime: Until delisting requested.
Notes: Requires registration of administrator and hosts to use. Removal requests are typically investigated and processed within 12 hours of submission if provided with a valid explanation

Listing goal: Bad reputation, difficult to identify the responsible, dynamic IP, SLAAC flag without genuine email service and inappropriate use of the URL
Nomination: Provides a list of IPv4/IPv6 addresses and domains which are sending spam or phishing.
Listing lifetime: Until delisting requested or seven days with good reputation.
Notes: The feedback system runs at SMTP layer. See https://spfbl.net/en/feedback

Nomination: {{strikethrough|2 virus mails sent to an associated system.}}
Listing lifetime: {{strikethrough|Automatic delisting. Listed as long as there were more than 2 virus mails sent in the last week.}} Offline Since May 2016
Notifies upon listing: {{no|{{strikethrough|No}} |- ! LashBack ! UBL | ubl.unsubscore.com | IP addresses which have sent email to addresses harvested from suppression (opt-out) files | Traps | For 30 days after last offending message unless removal is requested | | {{No}} | {{No}} |- ! 0Spam Project ! DNSBL | 0spam.fusionzero.com | Spam Traps | A single IP(127.0.0.#) is listed upon sending spam to a spam trap, sending from multiple IPs within a range within a short period of time will result in a class C listing(127.0.#.0). | Until an IP owner/authorized admin requests listing removal. | Single IP Listed with Data result 127.0.0.# Class C IP Block Listed with Data result 127.0.#.0 Codes are as follows: (ie. General spam single IP result 127.0.0.1 ) general spam, Sending spam to our spam traps. Removal request made but missing required information, please make a new request and be sure to complete the form properly. Does not follow valid can-spam rules for newsletters / lists. Not RFC compliant, server errors or improper configuration. Repeat offenders, these are IP's that have been removed and listed again (3) or more times in a short period of time. Bouncing email to the wrong server, RFC-non-compliant configurations. Relay or Open relay with reports of spam. bouncing spoofed emails, you need to disable bounce of spoofed emails in order to get de listed. Fraud/Scam emails, malware or illegal/abusive content. | {{No}} | {{No}} |} Notes "Collateral Listings" - Deliberately listing non-offending IP addresses, in order to coerce ISPs to take action against spammers under their control. "Notifies upon listing" - Warns the owner of the IP/Domain when they list an IP. (so owners can take action to fix the problem) References {{Reflist}} External links Blacklist Checker queries the major DNS Blacklists for specific IP address and returns whether it is listed for any malicious activities.
